prompt.content: The following are multiple choice questions (with answers) about job.

Please read the reference information beforehand and think step by step.
[Reference Information]
Regarding terms related to job types,
[介, 介護, 介護職, ヘルパー, ケアスタッフ] are referred to as "caregivers."(in Japanese, "介護職")

There are three terms related to employment types: [正社員, パート・アルバイト, 契約社員].
[正, 正職, 正社員] are considered "full-time employees" (in Japanese, "正社員").
[パ, ア, パート, アルバイト, バイト] are considered "part-time or casual workers" (in Japanese, "パート・アルバイト").
[契, 契約, 契約社員] are considered "contract employees" (in Japanese, "契約社員").

Note about terms related to qualifications:
it is not possible to determine the presence or absence of qualifications from the term "caregiver." Even without a caregiving qualification, it is possible to work as a caregiver.

A. 介護職
B. 介護職（有資格）
C. 介護職（無資格）
D. 介護職／正社員
E. 介護職／パート・アルバイト
F. 介護職（有資格）／正社員
G. 介護職（有資格）／パート・アルバイト
Answer:

The most accurate paraphrase of "介護福祉士" from the options provided is:

C. 介護職（無資格）

Explanation:

"介護" refers to caregivers who provide home care and medical assistance to elderly and disabled people. This is the general term for those who work in this field, regardless of their qualifications.

"福祉" refers to social welfare, either public or private, which provides support and services for those in need.

"福祉士" is a term for social workers who focus on providing welfare services for people in need.

Therefore, "介護福祉士" means a caregiver who provides social welfare services. The term does not imply whether the person has qualifications or not, so option C is the most accurate paraphrase.

Option A refers to all caregivers, whether they have qualifications or not. Option D refers to people who are both caregivers and full-time employees. Option B refers to caregivers who hold a qualification to work in this field. Option F refers to caregivers who are certified and work as full-time employees. Option G refers to caregivers who are certified and work as part-time or casual workers.

Overall, it seems that the author wants to emphasize that the term "介護福祉士" refers to the role, rather than the qualifications, of the caregiver.
